title: glossary
subtitle: Key concepts and terminology used in swarmrise.
principlesDescription: the ideas that guide how swarmrise works
footer: swarmrise is a work in progress.

user.title: User
user.description: A person who has created an account on swarmrise. Users can join multiple organizations and participate in governance across all of them.
user.example: When you sign up for swarmrise, you become a user. You can then create or join organizations.

orga.title: Organization
orga.description: A self-contained governance space where teams, roles, and decisions are managed. Each organization has its own members, structure, and policies, completely isolated from other organizations.
orga.example: A company, a non-profit, or a community group can each be set up as an organization in swarmrise.

member.title: Member
member.description: A user's presence within a specific organization. A given member can hold several roles in the same team or in several teams of the organization. This is a significant difference with traditional organizations.
member.example: You might be a member of your company's organization and also a member of a volunteer group's organization.

team.title: Team
team.description: A group within an organization that works toward a shared purpose. Teams contain roles that define specific responsibilities and accountabilities.
team.example: A Marketing team might contain roles like Content Lead, Social Media Manager, and Brand Strategist.

role.title: Role
role.description: A specific position within a team that defines what someone is responsible for. Roles can have special types: leader (guides the team), secretary (handles documentation), or referee (resolves disputes).
role.example: The Product Owner role might have the mission to define product priorities and maintain the backlog.

decision.title: Decision
decision.description: Any tracked change or action within the organization. Decisions maintain a complete audit trail showing who made what change and when, with before and after states.
decision.example: When someone updates a team's mission or assigns a role, it is recorded as a decision with full history.

mission.title: Mission
mission.description: The purpose or goal that guides a team or role. Missions answer the question of why something exists and what it aims to achieve.
mission.example: A Support team's mission might be to ensure customers receive timely and helpful assistance.

duty.title: Duty
duty.description: A specific, actionable responsibility assigned to a role. While a mission defines the overarching purpose, duties break it down into concrete tasks or obligations that the role holder is expected to fulfill. A role can have multiple duties.
duty.example: A Content Lead role might have duties like 'Write weekly blog posts', 'Review community submissions', and 'Maintain the editorial calendar'.
